author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Murderous Monarch
description: President Biden hasn’t pushed for real justice, but at least he’s not as obsequious as his predecessor.
content: The Biden administration formally acknowledged on Friday what President Donald Trump would not, that Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia approved the plan to kill the dissident journalist Jamal Khashoggi. But Mr. Biden seems to have concluded that the potential cost of taking action against the 35-year-old de facto ruler of a key American ally was simply too high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Myanmar Military Fires U.N. Envoy Who Spoke Against Its Coup
description: The regime fired the ambassador, U Kyaw Moe Tun, who called for international help in restoring democracy and gave the three-finger salute of the protest movement.
content: BANGKOK — Myanmar’s month-old military regime fired the country’s ambassador to the United Nations on Saturday, a day after he gave an impassioned speech to the U.N. General Assembly in New York, pleading for international help in restoring democracy to his homeland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Desperate Times, Creative Measures
description: Economic growth is the primary corrective for unemployment, but targeted aid can help people find jobs more quickly.
content: Millions of Americans are approaching a grim anniversary: one year without paid work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave and Michael Paulson
title: Broadway Is Dark. London Is Quiet. But in Australia, It’s Showtime.
description: Temperature-taking robots, scanning codes for contact tracing, and generous refund policies are helping shows like “Frozen,” “Come From Away” and “Hamilton” get back onstage.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — The lights were dimmed, the crowd was masked, and plexiglass divided the orchestra.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: CPAC and the New Republicanism
description: The Conservative Political Action Conference has evolved from a family reunion of Republican libertarians, social conservatives and a hawkish foreign policy establishment into Trump-chella.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Three Killed in Georgia Plane Crash
description: Officials said the plane, which was headed to Daytona Beach, Fla., crashed into a ravine in Gainesville, Ga.
content: Three people were killed on Friday after a single-engine plane crashed into a ravine outside of Atlanta, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Jewell Loyd Is in the Gym, Building Her Game and a Community
description: A trying year, on and off the court, helped Loyd finally embrace herself as an elite Black female athlete.
content: The Warehouse gym is a little off the beaten track, plopped south of an interstate highway, behind a hidden road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Berkshire Hathaway’s Earnings Slowed Last Year
description: But its results were bolstered by a soaring stock market in the fourth quarter, Warren Buffett said in his annual letter to investors.
content: Thanks to its huge collection of businesses — from insurance to railroads to candy — Warren E. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway is often seen as a barometer for the American economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Lawrence Otis Graham, 59, Dies; Explored Race and Class in Black America
description: An Ivy League-trained lawyer, he rose to prominence in the 1990s by examining the tensions that surround Black achievement and wealth.
content: Lawrence Otis Graham, an Ivy League-trained lawyer whose incisive, often searingly self-aware explorations of class identity and divisions among African-Americans made him one of the most widely read, and widely debated, Black writers of the 1990s, died on Feb. 19 at his home in Chappaqua, N.Y. He was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: How to Unite a Deeply Divided Kosovo? Name a Lake After Trump
description: A lighthearted suggestion by a U.S. envoy hoping to bridge a vast rift between Albanians and Serbs in Kosovo has taken on a life of its own — only to be ridiculed by local residents on both sides.
content: ZUBIN POTOK, Kosovo — Ljiljana Trifonovic, an ethnic Serb living in a waterside hamlet in northern Kosovo, never cared for American politicians — “they are all against us,” she said — but she took a shine to Donald J. Trump when he was in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere
title: F.D.A. Clears Johnson & Johnson’s Shot, the Third Vaccine for U.S.
description: The authorization of a third Covid-19 vaccine will bring millions more doses within days. But health officials worry that some people will see the vaccine as the inferior choice.
content: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration on Saturday authorized Johnson & Johnson’s single-shot Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use, beginning the rollout of millions of doses of a third effective vaccine that could reach Americans by early next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Some colleges and universities are planning for a ‘more normal’ fall semester.
description: Whether they can deliver hinges largely on factors outside their control.
content: Colleges and universities across the country are pledging to reopen more fully in the fall, with some administrators worried that students won’t return to campus if normality, or some semblance of it, isn’t restored by September.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Influencers Find Welcome in Paradise, While the Rest of Us Watch From Lockdown
description: By urging travelers to visit, the Maldives is reviving its luxury resorts. It’s also risking new outbreaks and courting controversy on social media.
content: In a season of lockdowns, Georgia Steel was jet setting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Michael Levenson
title: Lady Gaga’s Dogs Are Returned Safely
description: Thieves in Los Angeles stole the French bulldogs two days earlier, shooting the man who had been walking them on a Hollywood avenue.
content: Lady Gaga’s two French bulldogs were recovered unharmed on Friday in Los Angeles, the police said, two days after thieves stole the dogs and shot a man who was walking them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Unity Proves Elusive in Democrats’ Fight for $15
description: If the Democrats have a problem, it’s with the working class.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: What It’s Like to Work With a Matchmaker
description: Six customers of matchmaking services share their experiences. Their fees ranged from about $500 to $25,000.
content: With television shows like “Million Dollar Matchmaker” and “Indian Matchmaking,” and a pandemic that has made it harder for singles to meet organically, matchmaking is hot again. “There used to be this stigma around it,” said Eddie Hernandez, an online dating consultant in San Francisco. “Now a lot more people are asking me about it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Saudis Say They Intercepted Houthi Missile Attack Over Capital
description: The strike came a day after a mysterious explosion struck an Israeli-owned ship in the Gulf of Oman.
content: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — Saudi Arabia said Saturday it intercepted a missile attack over its capital and bomb-laden drones targeting a southern province, the latest in a series of airborne assaults it has blamed on Yemen’s rebel Houthis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: In Statehouses, Stolen-Election Myth Fuels a G.O.P. Drive to Rewrite Rules
description: Republican legislators want big changes to the laws for elections and other aspects of governance. A fight over the ground rules for voting may follow.
content: WASHINGTON — Led by loyalists who embrace former President Donald J. Trump’s baseless claims of a stolen election, Republicans in state legislatures nationwide are mounting extraordinary efforts to change the rules of voting and representation — and enhance their own political clout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Silvera
title: Out of the Wardrobe
description: With echoes of Narnia, David Levithan’s “The Mysterious Disappearance of Aidan S.” flips the script on traditional portal fiction.
content: THE MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE OF AIDAN S. (AS TOLD TO HIS BROTHER)By David Levithan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Biden Visits Storm-Battered Texas and Vows Federal Help ‘For the Long Haul’
description: The overwhelming nature of grief has been the unofficial theme this week for a White House confronted with a disaster in the nation’s second largest state amid a pandemic.
content: WASHINGTON — At an emergency response center in Houston on Friday, President Biden praised officials who had slept in stairwells as they worked around the clock to help people with no power or drinkable water because of the devastating storms, low temperatures and breakdown of basic utilities that had paralyzed Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Golden Globes 2021: What to Watch For
description: The Hollywood awards season starts in earnest with a socially distanced show that begins on Sunday at 8 p.m. Eastern. Streaming services are expected to dominate.
content: LOS ANGELES — “Mank,” David Fincher’s black-and-white tale of Old Hollywood, is nominated for six trophies at Sunday’s Golden Globe Awards, the most of any film. It has been available for viewing on Netflix since Dec. 4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: A Hedge Fund’s Bet on Criminal Justice
description: Topeka Sam, who helps women re-entering society after prison, gets more than just money from Daniel S. Loeb’s $16 billion firm, Third Point.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of a big issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: Speaking of Britney … What About All Those Other Women?
description: Monica Lewinsky. Janet Jackson. Lindsay Lohan. Whitney Houston. We are living in an era of reappraisals.
content: In 2007, Britney Spears, Lindsay Lohan and Paris Hilton were apparently fueling enough of a debate among parents about children and “values” for Newsweek to publish a cover story titled “The Girls Gone Wild Effect.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Want to Sanitize a Baseball Stadium? Send in the Drones
description: Don Wakamatsu’s day job is bench coach of the Rangers, but his background in farming led to an interesting solution for how to help fans feel safe.
content: On Wednesday morning, four days before spring training games were to begin and fans would return across Major League Baseball, a six-foot-wide drone flew throughout a 10,500-seat stadium in Surprise, Ariz., the preseason home of the Kansas City Royals and the Texas Rangers. The drone sprayed a cleaning solution that, according to its manufacturer, will protect surfaces from germs, including the coronavirus, for more than 30 days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Alyssa Schukar
title: They Were on Equal Footing. Then the Ground Shifted.
description: A year of pandemic restrictions has meant some friends are flush and others foundering.
content: Robin Arnone, a part-time trainer before the coronavirus pandemic, hasn’t set foot in the Colosseum Gym in Columbia, Md., since the virus shut it down almost a year ago. The gym is open again, but she doesn’t need the work. Things are going gangbusters in her other job as a home appraiser, and she hasn’t looked back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Yuval Waldman, Bridge-Building Violinist, Is Dead at 74
description: A conductor as well as a skilled soloist, he liked to spotlight music composed in times of oppression, including the Holocaust.
content: Yuval Waldman, an accomplished violinist and conductor with particular interests in building musical bridges between countries and rediscovering neglected works composed under oppressive circumstances, died on Feb. 1 in Brooklyn. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: ‘Captain Tom,’ the 100-year-old who raised millions for Britain’s health system, gets a hero’s goodbye at his funeral.
description: In the final year of his life, the decorated World War II veteran inspired people around the world with his patio laps and was knighted by Queen Elizabeth.
content: Tom Moore, the 100-year-old British national hero who raised millions of pounds for the National Health Service during the pandemic, was sent off with military honors at his funeral on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: He Came From Thailand to Care For Family. Then Came a Brutal Attack.
description: The fatal assault in San Francisco on a defenseless older man was the latest terrifying episode for Asian-Americans, many of whom have endured racist taunts, rants and worse during the pandemic.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Weary of being cooped inside during the pandemic, Vicha Ratanapakdee was impatient for his regular morning walk. He washed his face, put on a baseball cap and face mask and told his wife he would have the coffee she had prepared for him when he returned. Then, on a brisk and misty Northern California winter morning last month, he stepped outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucinda Rosenfeld
title: Heroines of Self-Loathing
description: What’s with all the female literary characters who can’t stand themselves?
content: For generations, Anna Karenina and Emma Bovary have loomed as the nonpareils of self-loathing literary heroines. For Anna, guilt over having abandoned her husband and child, paired with a jealous nature, compels her to destroy the love she shares with Count Vronsky — and head for the train tracks. For Emma, dumped by a conscience-free bachelor with whom she has an extramarital affair — and unable to repay the debts she accrues on account of her shopping addiction — a spoonful of arsenic ultimately beckons.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: States Itching to Open Up, to Dismay of C.D.C.
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 27, 2021.
content: “I know people are tired; they want to get back to life, to normal. But we’re not there yet.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Anyone Who’s Anyone Has a SPAC Right Now
description: A once obscure financial maneuver becomes a celebrity flex.
content: In simpler times, famous-people-turned-entrepreneurs bought wineries or invested in car dealerships — or simply created multi-billion-dollar lifestyle companies on the strength of their family brand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: How to Watch the Golden Globes 2021: Date, Time and Streaming
description: Here’s a quick guide with everything you need to know for the Hollywood Foreign Press Association film and television awards.
content: When the 78th annual Golden Globes are handed out on Sunday, they will be the first major awards show of the season, coming nearly two months after we would typically find out the best picture winner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: How One State Managed to Actually Write Rules on Facial Recognition
description: Massachusetts is one of the first states to put legislative guardrails around the use of facial recognition technology in criminal investigations.
content: Though police have been using facial recognition technology for the last two decades to try to identify unknown people in their investigations, the practice of putting the majority of Americans into a perpetual photo lineup has gotten surprisingly little attention from lawmakers and regulators. Until now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: At Last, Democrats Get Chance to Engineer Obamacare 2.0
description: The Biden administration is trying to make the health care law more generous and closer to its original design, but may disappoint progressive allies hoping for more.
content: Ever since the Affordable Care Act became law in 2010 — a big deal, in the (sanitized) words of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. — Democrats have itched to fix its flaws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Texans Demand Answers as They Grapple With Storm’s Lingering Wrath
description: After millions lost power during a winter storm, lawmakers have held marathon hearings, prosecutors have started criminal investigations and residents have asked for accountability.
content: HOUSTON — Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas has called for an overhaul of the agency that oversees the flow of electricity through much of the state. Prosecutors have initiated criminal investigations into power outages that affected millions of Texans. And several lawmakers have called for the chairwoman of the Public Utility Commission of Texas to resign, as energy officials were summoned to Austin for marathon hearings on what went wrong during last week’s destructive winter storm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elsie Chen and Sui-Lee Wee
title: China Tried to Slow Divorces by Making Couples Wait. Instead, They Rushed.
description: A new rule requiring a cooling-off period before a divorce could be granted led to an outcry, as well as a surge of applications to beat the deadline.
content: Last December, Emma Shi desperately needed an appointment at the civil affairs bureau in Shanghai, but could not get one. She scoured the internet to find someone who could help, quickly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jori Finkel
title: Smoky Artwork by Judy Chicago at Desert Zoo Is Canceled
description: “Living Smoke” was scheduled for April but the California venue withdrew after an activist said the colorful smoke display could harm the environment.
content: Two years ago, the arts organization Desert X in Palm Springs, Calif., canceled a Jenny Holzer light projection to be shown on a local mountainside during its biennial exhibition for fear of endangering bighorn sheep that roamed there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: My 6 Months as a Solo Parent
description: After my wife was deployed, I found myself caring for four kids on my own — something my mother did for my whole childhood.
content: It would be wrong to say I never appreciated the sacrifices of a solo parent. My mother, a single Black woman, has always been the hero of my story. She instilled hope in the hearts and minds of her four kids in a South that tended to quench the flickering light of possibility in the imaginations of Black children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Vulnerable Inmates Left in Prison as Covid Rages
description: At a federal compound in Connecticut, inmates in precarious health “are like sitting ducks,” one lawyer said.
content: Shacarey James was six weeks pregnant when she reported to the Federal Correctional Institution in Danbury, Conn., last summer to serve a sentence for a parole violation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: ‘Guernica’ Tapestry Is Taken Back From U.N. by a Rockefeller
description: The replica of Picasso’s famed painting depicting the horrors of war had hung outside the Security Council chamber since 1985, on loan from the Rockefeller family.
content: For more than three decades, a 25-foot long canvas tapestry replica of “Guernica” hung outside the United Nations Security Council chamber, the backdrop for speeches by diplomats who were working to avert the atrocities depicted in Picasso’s iconic antiwar painting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Cuomo Is Accused of Sexual Harassment by a 2nd Former Aide
description: The woman, 25, said that when they were alone in his office, Gov. Andrew Cuomo asked if she “had ever been with an older man.”
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — A second former aide to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is accusing him of sexual harassment, saying that he asked her questions about her sex life, whether she was monogamous in her relationships and if she had ever had sex with older men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Fred Segal, Designer Who Commodified California Cool, Dies at 87
description: His laid-back style and namesake jeans made him a touchstone of 1960s fashion, drawing celebrities and tourists alike to his stores.
content: Fred Segal, whose clothing boutiques became an emblem of Los Angeles cool by selling form-fitting jeans and chambray shirts to the likes of Bob Dylan, Farah Fawcett and the Beatles, died on Thursday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: N.B.A. Investigating After Jeremy Lin Said He Was Called ‘Coronavirus’
description: Lin, who is Taiwanese-American, said on social media that he had been called “coronavirus” on the court. He has been playing in the N.B.A.’s developmental league.
content: The N.B.A. G League said on Friday that it was investigating a report by Jeremy Lin, one of the best-known Asian-American players in basketball, that he had been called “coronavirus” on the court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Crossword Buff
description: Brad Wiegmann unveils, unmasks and undresses his debut Sunday puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Our constructor today, Brad Wiegmann, is brand-new, a babe in the woods, an innocent lamb. Mr. Wiegmann embarked on his dream of making a crossword over a year ago, while on vacation from his job as a national security lawyer for the United States Department of Justice. Make of that what you will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Federal Scientists Plead for Pandemic Controls as Infection Declines Stall
description: “Now is not the time to relax restrictions,” the C.D.C. director, Rochelle Walensky, said, pointing to a leveling of coronavirus infections as governors move to lift pandemic restrictions.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal health officials warned impatient governors on Friday against relaxing pandemic control measures, saying that a recent steep drop in coronavirus cases and deaths in the United States may be leveling off at a very high number — a shift that the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said “must be taken extremely seriously.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Gymnasts’ Abusers ‘Were Buds and Protected Each Other’
description: Coach John Geddert drove young gymnasts to the point of injury, then sent them to Lawrence G. Nassar, the doctor who abused them sexually. Geddert killed himself on Thursday in the face of criminal charges.
content: For several decades, until law enforcement finally came calling and their careers came to an end, the coach and the doctor were close friends who made a perfect team of abusers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Antoine Hodge, Opera Singer With a Powerful Work Ethic, Dies at 38
description: Mr. Hodge, a bass-baritone, was recently a chorus member in “Porgy and Bess” at the Metropolitan Opera. He died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: WeWork’s Path to Markets Is Cleared as Co-Founder and SoftBank Settle Suit
description: Adam Neumann was said to be selling $480 million of his shares to the Japanese conglomerate, which aims to take WeWork public.
content: Adam Neumann, a WeWork co-founder, and SoftBank, the co-working company’s largest shareholder, announced on Friday that they had settled their legal dispute, opening the way for WeWork to go public just 16 months after SoftBank rescued it from collapse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: Rapper’s Arrest Awakens Rage in Spanish Youth Chafing in Pandemic
description: Nearly two weeks of sometimes violent demonstrations have turned into a collective outcry from young adults who see bleak futures and precious time lost to lockdowns.
content: BARCELONA — It had all the markings of a free speech showdown: Pablo Hasél, a controversial Spanish rapper, had barricaded himself on a university campus to avoid a nine-month jail sentence on charges that he had glorified terrorism and denigrated the monarchy. While students surrounded him, police in riot gear moved in; Mr. Hasél raised his fist in defiance as he was taken away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How to Avoid Scams When Renting an Apartment
description: New York’s rental market has been turned upside down by the pandemic, making it hard to tell a good deal from one that’s too good to be true.
content: Q: I am moving to New York and need to look for an apartment. A friend told me to watch out for scams. What am I supposed to watch out for and how would I know if a listing is problematic?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: A Gymnastics Coach Was Charged With Human Trafficking. What Does That Mean?
description: Experts say the filing of human trafficking charges against John Geddert, who died on Thursday, could have major ramifications for future prosecutions of coaches in the high-pressure world of elite sports.
content: Of all the charges brought against the former U.S. gymnastics coach John Geddert on Thursday, the most alarming seemed to be the 20 counts of human trafficking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: It don’t take a weatherman to know that Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon have blown in with a very difficult puzzle.
content: ACROSTIC — I thought this was the hardest acrostic we’ve seen in quite a while, but it may have been poor luck on my part, because I started out with a couple of very wrong guesses. These contorted my deductions — I had “atheist” instead of INFIDEL and “emigrating” instead of LOCOMOTIVE, which created a totally different grammatical framing for the passage. That said, even though the excerpt is by a well-known American icon, it includes some unusual verbiage, and the cluing is tough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Minneapolis Will Pay Influencers to Fight Misinformation During Officers’ Trials
description: The city will pay six social media influencers $2,000 each to share messages during the trials of Derek Chauvin and three other former police officers charged in the killing of George Floyd.
content: The City of Minneapolis plans to pay social media influencers to spread city-approved messages as part of an effort to combat misinformation during the upcoming trials of the four police officers charged in the killing of George Floyd, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Latina Girls Dreaming
description: “Latinitas,” by Juliet Menéndez, introduces young readers to 40 Latina trailblazers, from the 17th century to the present, as children at play.
content: LATINITASCelebrating 40 Big DreamersBy Juliet Menéndez
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott and Jonathan Martin
title: Trump Loyalists Spurn ‘Failed Republican Establishment of Yesteryear’
description: At an annual gathering of conservatives, devotees of Donald J. Trump pledged their fealty to him and issued grave warnings about the political left.
content: ORLANDO, Fla. — One month after Donald J. Trump left office, thousands of his conservative allies and other far-right leaders on Friday began trying to center the Republican Party around the grievances of his presidency, pushing false claims about the American voting system, denouncing what they called liberal cancel culture and mocking mask-wearing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: How Marty Baron and Jeff Bezos Remade The Washington Post
description: The celebrated editor is ending his tenure at the helm of a very different newspaper than the one he originally signed on to run.
content: On July 30, 2013, Martin Baron left The Washington Post building and crossed 15th Street for an extremely rare happy hour drink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li
title: China’s Seniors, Seeking Retirement Homes, Find Scams Instead
description: Rooms and beds for retirees are in short supply as the population ages, leaving many vulnerable to companies pitching risky investments.
content: The saleswoman waited for Yang Jinzhong at the bus stop. She took Ms. Yang for a tour in her car. With every call and meeting, the saleswoman made the same pitch: By investing just a little bit of money, Ms. Yang could secure a spot in a retirement home at a great price and make some extra cash to boot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Christine Hauser
title: Digidog, a Robotic Dog Used by the Police, Stirs Privacy Concerns
description: The New York Police Department has been testing Digidog, which it says can be deployed in dangerous situations and keep officers safer, but some fear it could become an aggressive surveillance tool.
content: Two men were being held hostage in a Bronx apartment. They had been threatened at gunpoint, tied up and tortured for hours by two other men who pretended to be plumbers to get inside, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Palestinians Go Into New Lockdown While Awaiting Vaccines
description: Covid cases are surging again in the West Bank amid a dispute over Israel’s obligations toward the Palestinians in the occupied territories.
content: JERUSALEM — The Palestinian Authority on Saturday announced a new set of lockdown restrictions in the West Bank as coronavirus infections surge and Palestinians await the rollout of a significant vaccination program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Twilight of the Anti-Trump Idols
description: From Andrew Cuomo’s scandals to the European vaccine disaster, after Trump the failures of his foils have been laid bare.
content: Throughout the Trump presidency and especially in the Covid era, there was a quest for figures that could be held up as embodiments of everything that Trump’s opposition wanted to restore: reason, technical competence, idealism. Over time these figures took on the character of familiar dramatic archetypes — the Good Republican, the Heroic Whistleblower, the Beleaguered Expert, the Tough Blue State Governor, the Wise and Sophisticated Europeans.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Most Versatile Tool in Your Kitchen
description: No matter what you’re craving, we have a sheet-pan recipe for that.
content: If you find yourself searching NYT Cooking for a protein or vegetable you have handy, one thing’s (likely) for certain: There’s a sheet-pan recipe for that. It’s no surprise that sheet-pan dinners made the list of our most popular recipes this week. Try Yewande Komolafe’s gochujang chicken, Yasmin Fahr’s sausage meatballs and Ali Slagle’s supple salmon (above), or break out the Dutch oven instead for Alexa Weibel’s vegan Bolognese or Lidey Heuck’s braised white beans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: This Drug Gets You High, and Is Legal (Maybe) Across the Country
description: A once-ignored derivative of hemp has become a hot seller for people looking for a loophole around marijuana laws.
content: Texas has one of the most restrictive medical marijuana laws in the country, with sales allowed only by prescription for a handful of conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: High on Their Own Supply
description: Democrats work the refs.
content: WASHINGTON — I’ve been waiting for this moment. The moment when some on the left would react indignantly to journalists doing their job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: What It Will Take to Get Life Back to Normal
description: At last, Covid vaccine shots are going into arms in significant numbers, but too many people could still fall through the cracks.
content: Vaccines have brought the United States tantalizingly close to crushing the coronavirus within its borders. After months of hiccups, some 1.4 million people are now being vaccinated every day, and many more shots are coming through the pipeline. The Food and Drug Administration has just authorized a third vaccine — a single-dose shot made by Johnson & Johnson — while Pfizer and Moderna are promising to greatly expand the supply of their shots, to roughly 100 million total doses per month, by early spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: I Will Not Rest Until This Garden Grows
description: Letting nature take its course is getting harder to do.
content: NASHVILLE — I recently started my garden in the middle of an ice storm. Sleet and snow poured down while I trudged out to the toolshed to fetch the seeds I’d saved from last year’s pollinator patch. Still, it was time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Rwanda Official Admits Legal Violations in ‘Hotel Rwanda’ Case
description: A video, aired by Al Jazeera English, shows that the attorney general intercepted legal materials from Paul Rusesabagina, who was portrayed in the movie “Hotel Rwanda” and is accused of terrorism.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Rwanda’s attorney general inadvertently revealed that he had intercepted privileged and confidential legal materials in the ongoing terrorism case against Paul Rusesabagina, the prominent dissident whose efforts to save more than 1,200 people during the country’s genocide was portrayed in the Oscar-nominated movie “Hotel Rwanda.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: A Quiet Life Out of the Spotlight? Not for This Former President
description: Most presidents leave the White House and adopt low profiles. Donald Trump is returning to the national stage with a prominent appearance at a conservative conference on Sunday.
content: For decades, the normal course of action for presidents departing the White House has been to lie low and let their successors have the stage to themselves in their first months in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Younger Military Personnel Reject Vaccine, in Warning for Commanders and the Nation
description: About one-third of the troops have declined to take the vaccine. Many say they worry the vaccines are unsafe or were developed too quickly. Others want a sense of independence, even in uniform.
content: WASHINGTON — Americans who go into the military understand the loss of personal liberty. Many of their daily activities are prescribed, as are their hairstyles, attire and personal conduct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Assessing Claims in the Coronavirus Stimulus Debate
description: Lawmakers have made an array of misleading claims about “Pelosi’s subway,” unauthorized immigrants receiving checks, school funding and the minimum wage as they debate the $1.9 trillion relief bill.
content: Ahead of the vote on President Biden’s $1.9 trillion stimulus package, lawmakers have offered an array of misleading claims to promote their position on the bill. Here’s a fact check of some common talking points.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter and Kiana Hayeri
title: ‘I Wake Up and Scream’: Secret Taliban Prisons Terrorize Thousands
description: A potential U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan, coupled with a weak Afghan security force, mean the Taliban will likely continue to capture, condemn and torture thousands.
content: FAIZABAD, Afghanistan — The Taliban prison is a ruined house, a cave, a filthy basement in an abandoned dwelling, or a village mosque. Beatings or worse are a certainty, and the sentence is indefinite. Food, if there is any, is stale bread and cold beans. A bed is the floor or a dirty carpet. The threat of death — screamed, shouted, sometimes inflicted — is ever-present.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Jim Tankersley
title: House Passes $1.9 Trillion Stimulus as Democrats Work to Salvage Wage Raise
description: Even as the House passed President Biden’s pandemic aid plan with a minimum wage increase included, Democrats were searching for a Plan B for the wage hike, which was ruled out in the Senate.
content: WASHINGTON — The House passed President Biden’s $1.9 trillion stimulus plan early Saturday in a nearly party-line vote, advancing a sweeping pandemic aid package that would provide billions of dollars for unemployed Americans, struggling families and businesses, schools and the distribution of coronavirus vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: In the Cloud, Say
description: Yacob Yonas brings us a stellar Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This grid blends an effortless mix of old and new, although it’s certainly a tough enough solve for the day. Yacob Yonas constructs themed and themeless puzzles for The Times, and I think you can see hints of a themey brain in pairs and groups of clues that work neatly together. As far as the eras referred to, I imagine that there’s a bunch of solvers who know their YouTubers and their George Sand — those of you who knew neither can come sit by me!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Jim Tankersley
title: Biden Agenda Faces Difficult Test as Stimulus Measure Heads to Senate
description: The $1.9 trillion pandemic aid bill narrowly passed the House, but now must maneuver through a procedural and political thicket in the Senate.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s agenda is facing its most consequential test as Democrats prepare to maneuver his $1.9 trillion stimulus package through the evenly divided Senate, an effort that could strain the fragile alliance between progressives and centrists and the limits of his power in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Bartzokas, Mika Gröndahl, Karthik Patanjali, Miles Peyton, Bedel Saget and Umi Syam
title: Why Opening Windows Is a Key to Reopening Schools
description: A simulation of airflow in a real New York City classroom shows how simple ventilation and filtration can reduce the probability of coronavirus exposure.
content: A simulation of airflow in a real New York City classroom shows how simple ventilation and filtration can reduce the probability of coronavirus exposure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: House Passes $1.9 Trillion Coronavirus Relief Plan
description: The House’s near party-line vote of 219 to 212 on Saturday advances President Biden’s sweeping pandemic relief package to the Senate.
content: The House’s near party-line vote of 219 to 212 on Saturday advances President Biden’s sweeping pandemic relief package to the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Canada Approves AstraZeneca Vaccine
description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced on Friday that Canada’s drug regulator had authorized the AstraZeneca vaccine as well as the version produced by the Serum Institute of India.
content: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced on Friday that Canada’s drug regulator had authorized the AstraZeneca vaccine as well as the version produced by the Serum Institute of India.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: CPAC Crowd Cheers Josh Hawley’s Vote Against Election Results
description: Senator Josh Hawley received a standing ovation at the Conservative Political Action Conference when he reminded the crowd that he had objected to certifying Joe Biden’s Electoral College victory.
content: Senator Josh Hawley received a standing ovation at the Conservative Political Action Conference when he reminded the crowd that he had objected to certifying Joe Biden’s Electoral College victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: House Democrats Say Stimulus Bill ‘Meets the Moment’
description: House Democrats are close to approving President Biden’s $1.9 trillion stimulus plan despite the Senate parliamentarian’s ruling that including a gradual increase to the federal minimum wage would violate budgetary rules.
content: House Democrats are close to approving President Biden’s $1.9 trillion stimulus plan despite the Senate parliamentarian’s ruling that including a gradual increase to the federal minimum wage would violate budgetary rules.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 27, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 27, 2021.
content: An article on Friday about the future of the coronavirus described incorrectly vaccination efforts in Kazakhstan. About 20,000 health care workers received their first vaccine shot this month, according to the country’s health ministry; it is not the case that no one in the country has been immunized.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Helping Americans Left Behind
description: Readers are moved by Nicholas Kristof’s account of the struggles and death of a childhood friend. “It is too late to save Mike Stepp,” a writer says. “It is not too late to save millions of others.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
